key_points: The IRS has begun distributing the second stimulus checks, offering $600 for each eligible adult and child.
Direct deposits have started and will continue into the week, while paper checks began mailing on December 30 for those without bank information on file.
Many recipients are uncertain about the exact arrival of their checks due to the IRS' "Get My Payment" website being offline.
This stimulus follows a first round from the CARES Act, which had issues such as delayed payments for those without bank info on file.
The IRS will distribute funds using the same methods as the first round, according to Mark Steber, chief tax information officer at Jackson Hewitt.
The "Get My Payment" tool is expected to resume operation next week, also tracking both the first and second stimulus payments.
Automatic payments will be made to those who filed a 2019 tax return, receive specific government benefits, or used the Non-Filers tool by November 21.
The payments are not taxable, and recipients are advised to keep IRS Notice 1444 for any additional amount due on their 2020 tax return.
Senate Majority Leader McConnell blocked a vote to increase the stimulus checks to $2,000, as requested by President Trump.
The second stimulus allows more people to be eligible, including mixed-status households previously denied under the CARES Act.
spokespersons: Mark Steber (Chief tax information officer, Jackson Hewitt)
